awd_titl_txt: Resolving Abnormal Target Erosion in High Frequency Magnetron Discharge
awd_abstract_narration:
Radio frequency (RF) magnetron sputtering is an essential technology for manufacturing a broad variety of high-quality thin films. The ceramic targets, the source of the thin film coating material, consumed during the RF sputtering process are expensive, thus efficient target consumption is highly desirable in lowering manufacturing costs. Incomplete understanding of the ceramic target etching mechanisms occurring during RF magnetron sputtering results in poor target use rates (~30%). This award supports fundamental research aimed at understanding RF magnetron discharges and how they induce target consumption.  New knowledge obtained on the complicated RF discharge processes will contribute to plasma science and technology, and will ultimately provide guidance on efficient RF magnetron design. Results from the research are expected to double the use rates of target materials. This will have a positive impact on many industrial fields including large-area optical coatings, energy storage, displays, solar energy, and semiconductor devices. The annual market of these fields has reached over $500 billion and is growing continuously. This project will strengthen university-industry collaborations and economic competitiveness of the U.S. by greatly reducing manufacturing costs of thin films. It will also contribute to workforce development by attracting and training graduate and undergraduate students in science and engineering.

RF magnetron sputtering is essentially determined by the non-uniform electromagnetic fields that vary with time and in space. Charged particles that lead to the sputtering of the target undergo complicated interactions with the non-uniform fields. Understanding high-frequency plasma discharges under the confinement of magnetic fields is a challenge and holds strong scientific appeal. Despite the scientific community's strong interest in high-frequency plasma discharges, knowledge in RF magnetron sputtering is very limited, which results in unsatisfactory RF magnetrons. In fact, current magnetrons are designed for achieving optimum performance in direct current (DC) sputtering, which is used for target materials that are electrically conducting like metals. When this same magnetron is used for RF sputtering of insulator targets, it is extremely ineffective and produces an abnormal erosion profile completely different from that in DC sputtering. Specifically, the intensively etched region under DC sputtering is the least eroded under RF sputtering. To understand the mechanisms of the abnormal RF target erosion and fill the knowledge gap, the research team hypothesizes a 'localized charge effect', which assumes that electrons in RF magnetron discharges preferentially accumulate and stay immobile on the insulator target surface near the magnet poles to attract ions to sputter these regions. This hypothesis is unexpected from the existing knowledge on magnetron sputtering and is thus potentially transformative. The research includes two major tasks: 1) modeling of RF magnetron discharges, and 2) verifying the 'localized charge effect' by designing a highly efficient RF magnetron through modeling and experimentally testing.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Radio-frequency (RF) magnetron sputtering is widely used for manufacturing a broad variety of high-quality thin films. The sputtering targets are expensive and efficient target consumption is highly desirable to lower manufacturing costs and improve process stability. Conventional magnetrons are designed for achieving optimum performance in direct current (DC) sputtering. Industry and research labs currently use DC-optimized magnetrons for RF sputtering. However, RF sputtering causes an abnormal target erosion profile completely different from DC sputtering, and this phenomenon is not currently understood. This gap in knowledge leads to inappropriately designed RF sputtering magnetrons that have very low (<30%) utilization of the target material.

The major goal of this project is to understand the mechanisms of the abnormal target erosion in RF magnetron sputtering and generate the necessary knowledge to guide the design of efficient magnetrons.

We first developed an efficient particle-in-cell Monte-Carlo collision scheme and used it to simulate the plasma discharges of a conventional RF sputtering magnetron. We validated the hypothesis of a ?localized charge effect?, which confirms the preferential charge accumulation in the areas where the magnetic field flux is perpendicular to the target surface. This study reveals the mechanisms of the abnormal target erosion in RF magnetron sputtering, i.e., the charge accumulation induces a local electric field that attracts the ions to sputter the region. Based on this discovery, we developed a new RF sputter magnetron and compared its performance with a commercial product. We demonstrated a significantly improved target erosion uniformity ? the target utilization rate increased from the conventional 58% to ~84%. In addition, the new RF magnetron resulted in much higher thin film deposition rates ? the deposition rates for SiO2 increased from the conventional 4.58 nm/min to 7.88 nm/min. This increase in the deposition rate is due to the uniform distribution of the charges on the target surface in the new magnetron.

In terms of broader impacts on society, the knowledge developed through this project provides guidance for designing high-performance RF sputtering magnetrons. These magnetrons directly impact the vacuum and coatings industry. This research also resulted in the development of a patented single beam plasma source that can greatly improve the crystallinity of thin films deposited at low temperatures. Further funding from the Michigan Economic Development Corporation has been awarded to commercialize this plasma source. A company recently licensed this technology from MSU and received NSF SBIR to develop commercial products. Two graduate and two undergraduate students were trained through this project. The research has led to one awarded patent, two pending patent applications, eight publications, and multiple conference presentations.

 


Last Modified: 06/25/2022
Modified by: Qi H Fan

Image
  • A single beam plasma source discharges simultaneously with an RF sputtering magnetron.
    Qi Hua Fan
    Copyrighted
    Qi H Fan
    Magnetron and Ion Source Discharges
